newsitem.title: GERMANY: German coffee buyers await further price falls.
newsitem.headline: German coffee buyers await further price falls.

text.p: German coffee roasters are staying out of the raw materials market for now because they are hoping for further futures falls, traders said on Monday.
New York arabica futures had a good chance of extending a reversal on profit-taking, which quickly followed new highs on the nearby contracts last week, they said.
"We haven't seen all of the likely downward correction... nevertheless prices will remain at high levels this year because of tight physical supply," one trader said.
Others agreed futures might pull back in a correction to rapid gains over the last six weeks and supported by encouraging supply fundamentals news from a number of Latin American countries.
New York March ended at 174.80 cents/lb, off 3.65, and May at 161.85, off 4.55, last Friday.
Traders believed the market could shed another 10 or 20 cents but this would still be well up from early 1997.
On the demand side, roasters were focusing on retail markets, where they plan to raise roasted coffee prices by around 1.50 marks per 0.5 kg from March 10.
"A certain amount of hoarding is going on at the moment in anticipation of the price rises and this is boosting roastings," one trader said.
"But the coffee firms are worried consumption might drop once the increases become effective."

Roasters' costs have risen by up to 70 percent since December amid futures rallies and dollar firmness, market leader Kraft Jacobs Suchard said last Friday in a statement justifying the price increases.
In the Northern German import markets, arabica prices were $4-7 down on the week per 50 kg fob but Colombia excelso was up $2 at $212.
Brazils were at $179 fob and Vietnam robustas at $68 cif.
Consumers last week bought some Brazilian and central American arabicas and robustas from all origins for 1997 as well as African and Asian arabicas for the first half.
Importers expected the Kenyan coffee season to end earlier than in recent years because of a smaller crop.
Sales volumes and prices at the next auction were expected to be high and Ethiopian and Zimbabwean prices were also seen benefiting from that. -Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275
